body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

I think `fused_type` is a great feature.

However, its performance is not quite sufficient for usage for lower level functions.

On my machine it adds extra 350ns for a call.
Which makes sense as it is approximately the same overhead that I see in `functools.singledispatch`.
Thus, I imagine it does a proper cascading/inheritance thing prioritising more strict types over more general.

One possible optimization could be to check for exact types first.
In `C` this would be pretty much for free.

This would be very helpful at least for the case of 1 fused type.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

_No response_

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body: Thanks for the report. Could you provide a complete (and short) example that shows what you are doing and how you measure the time on your side?

```python
import cython as cy

cy_num = cy.fused_type(cy.long, cy.int)

def no_overloading(a: cy.long):
    pass

def overloading(a: cy_num):
    pass

%timeit this.no_overloading(1)      #  24 ns
%timeit this.overloading(1)         # 400 ns
```

Obviously we do want it to perform as well as possible so should aim to improve it if possible. But some quick comments on this

1. Fused functions are best if you you call fused `cdef` functions from within Cython. That's usually resolved at compile-time so has 0 overhead.
2. Fused functions for scalar numeric types like this can end up a bit pointless. In your example the only signature that ever gets used is for `long` and the `int` variation is actually unreachable. I have some views on how to improve this (e.g. for Numpy scalar types) but it'd likely make things slower rather than faster. I realise this may just be because you're using a simplified example for illustration.

> 1. Fused functions are best if you you call fused `cdef` functions from within Cython. That's usually resolved at compile-time so has 0 overhead.

Ah, that is good to know, wasn't aware of it. This does solve big portion of cases where I want this to be faster. Python calls are a big part of my usage nevertheless.

> 2\. In your example the only signature that ever gets used is for `long` and the `int` variation is actually unreachable. ... I realise this may just be because you're using a simplified example for illustration.

Yes, this is just a made up example.
But good point, didn't even think of it.
A curiosity: Why calling a function having an argument with fused type so much comparing to regular C type?

> A curiosity: Why calling a function having an argument with fused type so much comparing to regular C type?

Uncomment (and change to Py3 style)

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/78f71849dcbccb87d12d7cf1e9c775fbf61547fc/Cython/Compiler/FusedNode.py#L816

There's just a reasonable amount of generated Cython code involved in picking the types

> ```python
> cy_num = cy.fused_type(list, object)
> 
> @cy.cfunc
> def _binary_func_internal(a: cy_num, b: cy_num):
>     pass
> ```

Note that this only generates two variants of your function, for lists and for other objects. If you want the cross-product, you have to use differently named fused types for `a` and `b`. (This is because it's much more common for real world code to _not_ want the cross-product.)

I think I can see a way to improve it.

First, profiling suggests that a large chunk of time is spent in `Py_ListNew` so I think we've got a number of unnecessary list allocations.
Second, everything in this block https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b862800bda6cc5f540d3b7961350cd2b6ad00dbd/Cython/Compiler/FusedNode.py#L776 is identical for all fused functions so it's probably worth factoring out into hand-written utility code. That's help share common code, and also hopefully give us something a bit better.
Third, it *may* be worth special-casing the one argument case.

I'll give it a go.

I took the liberty to borrow the time machine keys and dropped them back right when I took them.
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7097
I won't do anything for now then...
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7098 should bring a major performance improvement for the function dispatch.
@dg-pb could you please try the PR to see if you get something similar with your own code?

> [@dg-pb](https://github.com/dg-pb) could you please try the PR to see if you get something similar with your own code?

What does it mean ordered vs unordered and Cython vs L-Cython?

Python 3.14.0 is uncompiled pure Python run?

> What does it mean ordered vs unordered

That just looks to be slight differences in how the benchmark runs through the function arguments. I'm not sure what realistic difference we'd expect that to make off the top of my head.

> and Cython vs L-Cython?

L-Cython is with the limited API. That's expected to be a little slower.

> Python 3.14.0 is uncompiled pure Python run?

Yes. Not sure how meaningful that is here. It's just measuring a function call so doesn't do any kind of dispatch based on the type

> > What does it mean ordered vs unordered
> 
> That just looks to be slight differences in how the benchmark runs through the function arguments. I'm not sure what realistic difference we'd expect that to make off the top of my head.

Bad naming on my side, I guess, but the `ordered` benchmarks simulates a case where the same dispatch type code is perpetually executed (thus benefiting from caching effects, branch prediction, etc.) and the `unordered` case runs the dispatch essentially in random order, changing branches on each execution. Both seem valid but different use cases, and there seems to be a visible performance difference, so I wanted to cover both in the benchmarks.

> > Python 3.14.0 is uncompiled pure Python run?
> 
> Yes. Not sure how meaningful that is here. It's just measuring a function call so doesn't do any kind of dispatch based on the type

… which makes it a lower bound for the call, allowing us to estimate how much time we lose in the dispatch.

> L-Cython is with the limited API. That's expected to be a little slower.

NOT limited api.
```python
# Typedef:
cy_num = cy.fused_type(cy.longlong, object)
cy_num2 = cy.fused_type(cy.longlong, object)

1-arg
baseline 400
new      170
2-arg
baseline 620
new      270
```
This I think would be ordered as I simply run the call with `%timeit`.

But my machine is quite old. And I am on OSX. That could explain differences I think.

But all in all, improvement is clearly visible.

---

I think special casing 1 arg case would also be beneficial. I don't know about the statistics of use cases, but personally I have only used 1 fused type so far.

And 2 arg special case would most likely cover my use cases many years ahead, but I imagine it is a bit more complicated and might not be worth it.
Maybe we could leave this open? @da-woods mentioned he might look into special casing 1-fused-type-arg. There is a chance that I will get to this as well, unlikely very soon, but still.

>  [@da-woods](https://github.com/da-woods) mentioned he might look into special casing 1-fused-type-arg.

That's done already. I don't currently know of anything obvious that I plan to look at for this

> > [@da-woods](https://github.com/da-woods) mentioned he might look into special casing 1-fused-type-arg.
> 
> That's done already. I don't currently know of anything obvious that I plan to look at for this

Ok then. Thank you. This will be very useful to me, hopefully others too.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: [ENH] fused_type performance
